awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Controlling Flow Separation via Traveling Wave Actuators
awd_abstract_narration:
Flow separation over a wing or fan blade leads typically to a significant loss of lift, thrust, or power, an increase in drag, an increase in fuel consumption, etc. Consequently, flow separation over these surfaces should be prevented with design or controlled. To control flow separation in this project, the flow near the surface is energized through triggering instabilities by a new lightweight, energy-efficient actuator that generates traveling waves. The main goal of this project is to test the hypothesis that this actuation is more efficient than other means and to optimize the performance of this actuator by gaining an understanding of the key parameters that govern the interaction of the actuator with the flow. This project will create a series of educational videos and the engagement of a diverse group of undergraduate students through well-established programs at our institutions. 

The main hypothesis of this proposal is that traveling wave actuators perform better than other actuators that create standing waves because: 1) traveling waves also inject momentum (generate thrust), and 2) apart from frequency, an additional parameter (wavelength) can also be tuned to affect flow separation as demonstrated by the preliminary results. Numerical and experimental approaches will be used for flow on a typical airfoil (NACA0018). Large-eddy simulations (LES) with moving boundaries will provide possible traveling waves for the initial design of traveling wave actuators and elucidate the mechanisms of flow reattachment. The experiments in the wind tunnel will provide the data to validate the simulations and confirm the hypothesis by comparing the traveling against standing wave actuators. The team?s synergistic capabilities in generating traveling wave via piezoelectric actuators and the wind tunnel experiments as well as LES with moving boundaries and fluid-structure interaction uniquely position us to tackle this challenge and accomplish the tasks put forward in this proposal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview: This project explored the use of innovative traveling wave actuators for controlling airflow over aerodynamic surfaces, such as aircraft wings, to improve performance and efficiency. The main goal was to demonstrate that traveling wave actuators could significantly reduce drag, delay flow separation, and increase lift compared to traditional methods like synthetic jets. This research has the potential to enhance the design of more efficient and environmentally friendly vehicles in the aerospace, automotive, and marine industries.

Intellectual Merit: The project made several key contributions to the field of flow control and actuator technology. Through a combination of numerical simulations and experimental testing, we developed a deeper understanding of how traveling wave actuators interact with airflow. These actuators generate waves that move along the surface of an airfoil, introducing an additional parameter—wavelength—that can be tuned to optimize aerodynamic performance. This novel approach offers a more effective means of controlling airflow compared to traditional methods that rely solely on frequency adjustments.

Key findings include:

  1. Improved Aerodynamic Performance: Traveling wave actuators were shown to significantly enhance lift and delay the stall angle of an airfoil. This improvement was achieved by actively controlling the separation of airflow from the surface, resulting in reduced drag and increased efficiency.
  2. Enhanced Flow Reattachment: The project demonstrated that traveling waves can promote reattachment of separated flow, leading to smoother and more stable aerodynamic behavior. This has important implications for the design of aircraft, wind turbines, and other applications where maintaining smooth airflow is critical.
  3. Development of Advanced Simulation Models: We developed and validated a coupled fluid-actuator interaction model that integrates the dynamics of the actuator with the surrounding airflow. This model provides a powerful tool for researchers to study complex flow control mechanisms and can be applied to various engineering challenges.

Broader Impacts: Beyond the scientific contributions, the project has made a significant impact on society, education, and technology.

  1. Environmental Benefits: The ability to reduce drag and improve fuel efficiency in vehicles can lead to lower emissions and a reduced environmental footprint. This technology has the potential to make air and sea travel more sustainable, aligning with global efforts to combat climate change and reduce the carbon footprint of transportation industries.
  2. Educational and Workforce Development: The project provided valuable training and hands-on research experience to graduate and undergraduate students, preparing them for careers in STEM fields. Educational modules and resources developed during the project have been integrated into university curricula, enriching the learning experience for students and inspiring the next generation of scientists and engineers.
  3. Community Outreach and Public Engagement: The project engaged with the broader community through workshops, public demonstrations, and educational outreach. These activities raised awareness of the role of advanced technologies in addressing societal challenges and inspired interest in STEM among young students.
  4. Infrastructure Enhancement: The project funded the purchase of a high-precision load cell for the wind tunnel, significantly enhancing the research capabilities of the facility. This equipment will support a wide range of future experiments, benefiting both the academic community and industry partners.

Conclusion: Overall, this project has advanced the understanding of flow control using traveling wave actuators and demonstrated their potential to improve aerodynamic performance. The outcomes have broad implications for environmental sustainability, education, and technology development. By bridging the gap between theoretical research and practical applications, this project has contributed to the progress of science and its benefits for society.

The findings from this research lay the groundwork for future innovations in vehicle design and energy efficiency, supporting a more sustainable and technologically advanced future.
